conversation.content:
**slightly cautious tone**

"It's going. And who am I speaking with?"
"Okay, Jacob. What company are you with, and what can I do for you? I've got a meeting in about ten minutes."

Yes sir. I just wanted to briefly reach out to you about automations in your company. I know a lot of companies now are excited about AI but they don't know where to start. So is there anything that's in your current workflow that you think could be used for automation? That is currently a gap.

**brief pause, slightly more engaged but still guarded**

"Well, Jacob, I appreciate the direct approach. Look, we've got plenty of manual processes that could probably benefit from automation - inventory tracking, demand forecasting, that kind of thing. But here's my question for you: what industry are you familiar with? Because I've had a lot of these calls lately, and most vendors don't really understand manufacturing operations. What kinds of companies have you actually implemented solutions for?"

**tone is professional but testing - wants to see if he's done his homework**

Yeah, it's good question, Sarah. So I'll be transparent with you. I don't have direct experience in the manufacturing industry. What I do have is more than 3 years working as a civil engineer. So I worked in construction. I had to deal with a lot of project management, I calculate quantities, make cost estimates. So I do have a pretty good understanding of kind of systems and you know project management and Logistics type processes. So I think that would Aid me and helping you build these Solutions.

**tone softens slightly - appreciates the honesty**

"Okay, I respect that you're being upfront about it. Construction and manufacturing do have some parallels with logistics and project management. But here's the thing - we're not starting from scratch. We've got legacy systems, an ERP that's been in place for years, and a team that's already stretched thin. 

What exactly are you proposing? Are you talking about building custom automation solutions for us, or do you have an existing platform? Because custom development sounds expensive and time-consuming, and I need to see ROI within 12 to 18 months max."

**leaning forward slightly, interested but cautious about scope and cost**

So I know that custom solution sound expensive, but the pro try usually take the company is is let's start with one small automation that we can show is working show and Roi get approve of Concepts and then so they will build on that cuz I think as I work with you more, we get to understand your process is better. You'll also understand what is actually able to be automated, then maybe you didn't before. So it's very much a partnership and a working collaboration and I can honestly keep costs pretty low on my end if we start small. So we can we can see, you know, my goal is to get you Roi very quickly and we can see the best path to doing that.

**thoughtful pause, pen tapping on desk**

"Okay, that's a more reasonable approach than some pitches I've heard. Starting small makes sense - I don't have appetite for a massive implementation right now anyway.

But let me ask you this: what does 'pretty low' mean in actual numbers? And what would that first small automation actually look like? Because I need something concrete to even consider this. Are we talking a few thousand dollars, tens of thousands? And more importantly, what's your process for understanding our operations well enough to identify the right starting point?

I'm not going to hand over our processes to someone who doesn't really understand what we do day-to-day."

**tone is direct but not dismissive - he's earned a bit more of her time with his honesty and reasonable approach**

Yeah, it's a great question, Sarah, and I'll be honest with you, right now, I'm getting started. I'm bootstrapped, I don't have a big team. I'm willing to put in the time and effort to build relationships, and bring on clients. And so, if that means that, I don't really see the fruits of my labor for a long time, then at this point and my, and my, you know, Journey, I'm all right with that. So, when you say 10,000 that would be very far down the line once I've proven myself and we agree that there's something to work with. So starting out, it'd be very low, I mean, I'm talking maybe even 100.00 for the first, you know, work together. I have a targeted, maybe interview with someone on your team. If we identify an area that we think is right product interview with that person, maybe 30 minutes, get to know the work clothes, get integrated in your systems and that's been a lot of time. On my end, understanding your systems to see the  rooms are

**long pause, tone shifts to more cautious and slightly concerned**

"Jacob, I'm going to be straight with you here. I appreciate the hustle, I really do - we all have to start somewhere. But what you're describing raises some red flags for me.

First, you're talking about getting integrated into our systems for essentially free. That's our proprietary data, our processes, our competitive advantage. I can't just give someone access to our ERP and operations without proper vetting, contracts, NDAs, and frankly, proof that you can deliver.

Second, a hundred dollars tells me you're either undervaluing your work or you don't really know what's involved yet. Either way, that makes me nervous about what happens six months from now when scope creeps and suddenly there's a much bigger bill.

What do you actually have to show me? Any case studies, even from construction? A portfolio? References?"

**tone is firm but not unkind - she's being protective of her company but also trying to give constructive feedback**

Yeah, that's a good point, Sarah, and to be honest, with the company of your size, probably isn't my best first client. So I think after this conversation, you know, maybe I'm going to establish this relationship and you are, and should not have nation and maybe I'll get a little more experience and reach out to online. Once I have a better game plan for you, how does that sound?

**tone warms up considerably, genuinely impressed**

"You know what, Jacob? That's really mature of you to recognize that. Most salespeople would just keep pushing. I respect that you're being realistic about where you are and what you can handle.

Here's my advice, since you've been honest with me: start with smaller companies - maybe 20 to 50 employees - where the owner or operations person can make quick decisions and take a chance on someone new. Build out two or three solid case studies with measurable results, even if you're doing it cheap or partially pro bono. Then come back to companies our size.

And when you do reach back out - if you want to in six months or a year - reference this conversation. I'll actually remember it. Good luck out there, Jacob. You've got the right attitude."

**genuinely encouraging, appreciates his self-awareness**

"Take care, Jacob."

**hangs up phone, makes a quick note on her desk pad: "Jacob - automation consultant, honest but green. Follow up in 6-12 months if he reaches out again."**

**glances at clock and heads toward her meeting**
